title: A Phase IIa Multi-Center Study of 18F-FDG PET, Safety, and Tolerability of AZD0530 in Mild Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: AZD0530 is an inhibitor of Src and Abl family kinases1. It has been developed as treatment for malignancies because these kinases play a role in tumor invasion and proliferation. However, the Src family kinases (SFKs) are highly expressed in brain and have major effects on synaptic plasticity2. Moreover, the investigators have recently shown that a specific SFK, namely Fyn, is aberrantly activated by specific conformations of the Amyloid Beta (Aß) peptide from Alzheimer's disease (AD). Genetic deletion of Fyn rescues AD deficits in preclinical models. This clinical trial will test the potential benefit of AZD0530 for Alzheimer's disease modification.

groups.title: AZD0530 100mg/125mg Daily
groups.description:
AZD0530 100mg daily: All patients in experimental group (50%) were started on 100mg AZD0530 daily

AZD0530 125mg daily: Patients with plasma drug level \<100ng/ml after 2 weeks of 100mg AZD0530 daily received 125mg daily of AZD0530.

groups.title: AZD0530 Placebo
groups.description: Placebo: 50% of patients will receive placebo treatment for the duration of the study.

groups.title: AZD0530 100mg Daily
groups.description:
Patients in the experimental group (50%) will be started on this dose. After 2 weeks, patients with a plasma drug level of \<100ng/ml will receive 125mg AZD0530 daily and remain in the same experimental group as patient receiving 100mg daily.

AZD0530 100mg daily: All patients in experimental group (50%) will be started on 100mg AZD0530 daily

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Brain Glucose Uptake Measured Using 18F-FDG PET Imaging
outcomeMeasures.description: Composite measure of brain glucose uptake using F18-FDG PET in a pre-defined set of brain regions, between baseline and 12 months.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Number of participants is lower than total randomized participants due to a modified intent-to-treat analysis where only randomized participants who also underwent a post-baseline F18-FDG PET brain scan are included.

outcomeMeasures.title: The Effect of Treatment With AZD0530 on Cognitive and Behavioral Function
outcomeMeasures.description:
The change in cognitive function between baseline and 12 months will be measured by the following tests:

1. Alzheimer Disease Assessment Scale - Cognitive 11 (ADAS-cog11). Measures: Cognitive function Maximum score: 70; Minimum score: 0. Higher score equals worse cognitive function
2. Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) Measures: Cognitive Function Maximum score: 30; Minimum score: 0. Higher score equal better cognitive function
3. Alzheimer Disease Cooperative Study - Activities of Daily Living Inventory (ADCS-ADL) Measures: Ability to perform routine daily activities Maximum score: 78; Minimum score: 0. Higher score equals better ability to perform activities of daily living
4. Clinical Dementia Rating Sum of Boxes (CDR-SO) Measures: Dementia severity Maximum score: 18; Minimum score: 0. Higher score equals more severe dementia.

explanation_target: Reason: The description states AZD0530 is an inhibitor of Src/Abl family kinases and that a specific Src family kinase (Fyn) is implicated in amyloid-β–mediated synaptotoxicity; the trial tests AZD0530 for Alzheimer’s disease modification, i.e., targeting AD pathology rather than only symptomatic cognitive enhancement. citeturn0search6turn0search1.

Act: AZD0530 is the small-molecule Src-family kinase inhibitor saracatinib (oral drug repurposed from oncology) and was evaluated in Phase Ib and Phase IIa AD trials including an 18F‑FDG PET, safety, and tolerability study — the trial title matches NCT02167256 / published reports. This identifies it as a disease‑targeted small molecule (not a biologic). citeturn0search5turn0search0.

Reflect: Classification confirmed — AZD0530/saracatinib is a small‑molecule kinase inhibitor intended to modulate an AD‑relevant pathological pathway (Fyn downstream of Aβ), so it fits the 'disease‑targeted small molecule' category rather than biologic, symptomatic cognitive enhancer only, or neuropsychiatric treatment. Key supporting sources: Phase Ib CNS availability report and Phase IIa randomized trial report / trial registry. citeturn0search1turn0search0turn0search5.
explanation_agent: Reason: AZD0530 (saracatinib) is an oral small‑molecule inhibitor of Src family tyrosine kinases (including Fyn), and Fyn mediates amyloid‑β oligomer–triggered postsynaptic signaling that causes synaptic dysfunction and loss — the mechanism is aimed at preventing synaptotoxicity and preserving synaptic function rather than directly removing amyloid plaques. citeturn0search6turn2search7

Act: Extracted details from the trial description — the investigational drug is AZD0530 (saracatinib), a disease‑targeted small molecule Src/Fyn kinase inhibitor; the Phase IIa study (NCT02167256) evaluated 18F‑FDG PET, safety and tolerability in mild AD patients, matching the provided trial title and registry entry. Based on the drug’s mechanism (modulation of Fyn‑dependent synaptic signaling), the most specific CADRO match is M) Synaptic Plasticity/Neuroprotection. citeturn0search3turn1search3

Reflect: Confirming the classification — although the Fyn pathway is activated downstream of amyloid‑β, AZD0530 does not directly target amyloid‑beta itself (CADRO A), nor is it a biologic or a general multi‑target neuropsychiatric/symptomatic agent; its therapeutic intent is to protect synapses and modulate synaptic signaling implicated in AD pathogenesis, fitting CADRO M. Supporting preclinical and early clinical rationale and summaries are documented in the literature and trial registry. citeturn0search1turn0search3
